reviewText:
How to get Fallout 3 to work on windows 8
1. Open ''File Explorer''
2. Double click ''Local Disk (C:)''
3. Double click ''Program Files (x86)''
4.  Locate & double click ''Steam''
5. Locate & double click ''steamapps''
6. Double click ''common''
7. Double click ''Fallout 3''
8. Right click ''Fallout3.exe''
9. Left click ''Properties''
10. Left click the ''Compatiblity'' tab
11. Check mark ''Run this program in compatibilty mode for:''
12. Under that it should be saying ''Windows Vista'' service pack 1 or service pack 2
13. Change it to ''Windows XP (Service Pack 3)'' DO NOT change it to Windows 8 or it won't work
14. Left click ''Apply'' then left click ''OK''
15. Locate your ''FalloutLauncher.exe'' folder
16. Right click ''FalloutLauncher.exe''
17. Left click on ''Properties''
18. Left click the ''Compatibility'' tab
19. Check mark ''Run this program in compatibility mode for:''
20.  Under that it should be saying ''Windows Vista'' service pack 1 or service pack 2
21. Change it to ''Windows XP (Service Pack 3)'' DO NOT change it to Windows 8 or it won't work
22. Left click ''Apply'' then left click ''OK''
23. Start up your game
24. Have fun!

((If it still doesn't work try installing this
http://www.xbox.com/en-CA/LIVE/PC/DownloadClient then the steps again))

Okay so I have had complaints about it not working and they do it how I said. So if you click on Fallout 3.exe" and right click on it
date: there may be no compatibilty tab. Don't worry it still works for your win
recommended: but I think that only happends on windows 10 but if you are on windows 8 or 7 and it is like that then don't worry your "hero" has a solution! xD So if "Fallout 3.exe" does NOT have a compatibility tab then there is probably something wrong with your game files. So just go back and highlight "Fallout 3" the one with the vaultboy logo and then that one should have your compatibilty. I really hope this review helps some people because spending money on stuff that you can't play stinks >:c."

reviewText:
Fallout 3 isn't just a game, It's an experience.

Wow, since I'am getting so many thumbs up, I feel I should write something useful about this game and why I personally recommend it.

+ One big continuous open world. Loading screens appear only when entering major cities or buildings.

+ Very atmospheric and immersive world to explore.

+ Every NPC’s are really living in that world. They follow their own daily routine from morning to night. You’ll meet them, talk to them and even remember their names.

+ Good writing and a touching story. It is fun to talk to NPC’s and trying out different dialogue options to see the outcome.

+ Freedom in almost every aspect. A quest can be completed in many ways. You can almost kill anybody you meet (even an entire town). You can be a good guy, a bad guy or have a mix of both. You can play as an action game or you can play stealthily. You can choose to play in 1st person or 3rd person. You can roam anywhere you want but….

+ Enemies don’t scale.  So if you wander off to the wrong area during early levels, you will die easily.

+ Many types of interesting enemies. Some are scary.

+ Graphics.

+ Voice acting.

+ VATS

+ Mods. A lot of them.

+ Galaxy News Radio and...

+ Three Dogs.


+- Progression system and level cap (max level 30). The progression system is fun and addictive (with a lot of useful perks to choose) but I personally prefer Elder Scroll’s progression system where you get better at what you use. This way you can shape your preferred character with more flexibility and can even change your play style anytime. That’s why it is not a negative, it’s something that I have a mixed feeling.

+- Dynamic day & night cycle. This game has day and night cycle but it is purely for cosmetic effect and doesn’t change or affect gameplay.


- A.I’s are stupid sometimes, especially if you play stealthily.

- Stealth gameplay could be better. Most area design doesn’t encourage stealth gameplay. No non-lethal option either.

- Crafting options are very few. (Mods fixes this)

- No iron sight aiming in 1st person. (Mods fixes this)

reviewText:
Immersive & stimulating // Recommended for marathon gamers looking to get lost in a world
This review is based on a purely vanilla playthrough.
+ RPG & levelling elements; fairly standard in practice, but work well and mesh perfectly with the feel of the game
+ Myriad available perks add enormous flexibility to a player's role
+ Karma system is a lot of fun to play around with, and also goes a long way to showcase the consequences of one's actions
+ Combat is fairly run-of-the-mill for an RPG FPS; certainly not fast-paced, but is implemented in a way that rewards planning and preparedeness
+ V.A.T. system functions well-beyond a simple gimmick; functional to the point of being vital in its proper use, intensely fun, and sensationally cinematic (save for one minor scruple, outlined below)
+ Environment, while graphically aged, is nonetheless incredibly detailed; there are always interesting things to find off the beaten path, and the player is encouraged in (and often rewarded for) exploring
+ Map is expansive and populated with secrets and locations to visit
+ Voice-acting is largely excellent, with only a few minor characters standing out as being less than exemplary in vocal quality
+ Side-missions are well-detailed, fun & interesting to complete; the rewards for doing so can sometimes be extraordinary
+ Plot moves forward at a pace set by the player, and is interesting to see through to the conclusion; writing ranges from passable to excellent, and never strays from the game's established charm
+ Total freedom in the way problems are solved and obstables overcome
+ Extremely, stupidly mod-friendly (via third-party applications - I recommend NexusMod, personally)
+ Modular damage, for both the player and encountered enemies, is very well-implemented; damage to certain areas of the body will hurt perfomance appropriately, further emphasizing a sense of immersion
+ Boasts a seemingly unending variety of items and weaponry; the hoarding game is real

- Oddly enough, this game uses GFWL, but is easily bypassed (simply by exiting out); this won't be counted thrice against the game (as GFWL, in this case, appears bafflingly neutered), but it does pop up, so it should be mentioned
- Camera can sometimes prove buggy and unreliable during V.A.T. kills
- Character models and animations are below-average in presentation (easily remedied via third-party mods, of course)
- There seems to be a bug where GFWL asks for a nonexistent product key; this is easily bypassed by simply exiding GFWL within the running game

If you enjoyed this review, please follow my curator page. Feel free to join my group, LockeProposal's Big Day Out for discussion and announcements, and I also have a budding YouTube Channel for those interested. Thanks for reading!

reviewText:
This is going to be a long reivew for Fallout 3 (YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED)

Set-Up: http://steamcommunity.com//sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=149946772
(Follow this guide in order to successfully play Fallout 3 on your Windows 7 & above)


After getting this game to work properly on my windows 8, it still stands out to be the 'better' (in my opinion) fallout game for this generation of gamers. No disrespect to Fallout: New Vegas but i feel that game focuses mainly on survival and a 'western' setting rather than a true 'post-apocalyptic' like you see in Fallout 3.

Mods make this game so much better, but however much more dangerous and unstable so install mods wisely. My advice? install small things like the street light mod and also install FOSE in order to get those working of couse and after maybe a couple of days of playing Fallout 3 with one simple mod gradually expand outward to big & better mods. Be careful though most mods require the DLC so get the DLC to the game ASAP (Which isn't a bad thing of course gives your system more 'breathing' room, but that's just my point of view).

If you want a true wasteland expereince install the F03 Wanderers Edition from the Nexus to get the LOL! 'hardcore' mode that F:NV had but Fallout 3 didn't

there is a ton of exploration to do in Fallout 3 (quicksave often) from the wasteland itself to the underbelly of the creepy, and dark subway systems. There is so much to do and so little time to do it.

The companions in this game aren't really all that great they charge into a heated battle with a 99% chance of dying depending upon who you are fighting (ironically i perfer F:NV compainon system as they are 'smarter' than the ones in Fallout 3)

By the end of the day Fallout 3 still stands as my personal  'post-apocalyptic' game to date, So if you want to explore the  harsh wasteland armed with an assault rifle and a whiskey bottle then this game is for you!

reviewText: When Fallout 3 was announced in 2004, not everyone was happy to hear that Bethesda would be the development studio to bring the Wasteland to life. The franchise's most hardcore fans were up in arms when they found out that their beloved Fallout was being turned into a first-person role-playing game, abandoning the originals' isometric perspective and dumbing it down" for consoles. Plenty of folks complained that the game would just end up being "Oblivion with guns" (of course
date: some would argue that that's not exactly a bad thing
recommended: as 2006's Elder Scrolls title was one of that year's finest RPGs). I can safely say that while Fallout 3 bears an uncanny resemblance to Oblivion in some ways
hoursPlayed: but it's also a far superior game in many others.\n\nIn the year 2077
voteText: nuclear war ravaged the world and forced a segment of the human race (well
helpfulPercent: the lucky ones anyway) underground to live out their days in massive Vaults that could protect them from the radiation-spawned terrors lurking outside in the Wasteland. Although the first two games in the Fallout series took place on the West Coast
votesHelpful: Fallout 3 is set in the greater Washington D.C. area. Naturally
votesTotal: this means you'll see plenty of familiar landmarks
votesFunny: from the Washington Monument to the White House. You may be saddened to see that the famed Tidal Basin cherry blossoms don't bloom during a nuclear winter.\n\nSome 200 years after this nuclear holocaust
commentsCount: your character is born inside of one of these subterranean sanctuaries. The game actually kicks off after a brief prologue
column16: with your character being forced out of the safety of your mother's womb into the hands of your waiting father. You'll take this time to name yourself and complete a "projection" of what you'll look like when you grow to adulthood
column17: at which point your father's face will finally come into view. It's an interesting way to handle character creation
column18: as well as show off the game's unique approach to presentation and customization.\n\nBefore leaving the safety of the Vault for the horrors of the world outside
column19: you'll need to determine what sort of character you'll be and how you'll approach the game. This begins when you find a book called "You're S.P.E.C.I.A.L.
column20:
which teaches you about the most basic level of character creation. This is where you'll set your core attributes that will determine your Strength, Perception, Endurance, and so on. These attributes remain largely the same as you progress through the game, although you'll have the rare chance to alter them with perks, equipment, or good old-fashioned drugs. Once you've set your core attributes, you'll need to take a test to determine which skills your character is most adept at using. Like Oblivion, you'll have just over a dozen skills that you can excel in, with three of those being marked as tag skills. After taking the Generalized Occupational Aptitude Test (G.O.A.T.), you'll learn which skills you're best-suited to using, although it should be noted that you can choose your own destiny and fight against the establishment that's telling you how to live your life by choosing the skills you want to focus on. The test is actually more of a psychological profile than an actual test, with your answers determining where your strengths lie.

While Fallout 3 could technically be called a first-person shooter, those looking for a Call of Duty 4-style experience will likely be disappointed. It's possible to run 'n gun your way through the game, but the FPS controls just aren't quite up to snuff. Thankfully this is alright since you've got the Vault-Tec Assisted Targeting System (VATS) to help you in combat. Utilizing VATS stops the action and allows you to target individual body parts, which are presented with the percentage chance that you have of successfully hitting them. You'll likely spend the majority of your time in combat using VATS, occasionally finishing off your foes in real-time when you run out of the action points that fuels VATS.

One area in which Fallout 3 doesn't resemble Oblivion is in its leveling system. While Oblivion rewarded you for doing specific things throughout the course of the game, here you'll only be able to upgrade your skills by earning experience points. These can be gained by doing everything from killing enemies and completing quests to winning speech challenges and successfully hacking computer terminals. There were times when I missed the ability to focus on improving a particular skill, although not having to spend hours practicing our sneaking skills just to gain a level or two was actually quite liberating.

While there are plenty of memorable characters and places throughout the game, the real star of the show is the massive, wide-open environment. It's incredibly easy to get distracted from the main quest, and that's part of the fun, as you'll find yourself getting sucked into one side quest after another as your explore the Wasteland. Of course, this can lead to moments when you'll need to spend an inordinate amount of time walking from one location to the next, as you can't use the game's fast-travel system if you haven't visited your target location at least once. There are times when it feels like a bit of a grind, though at least you'll stumble upon plenty of cool locations during your travels.

Given that it uses the same Gamebryo engine that powered Oblivion, it's probably not surprising to learn that Fallout 3 is a helluva great-looking game. Sure, the characters still look a bit weird while they're talking, and you'll likely notice some draw distance issues no matter which version you play, but this is still one of the most visually impressive games of 2008. The PC version looks particularly nice, especially since it runs at a smooth and steady 60 frames per second with only occasional dips.

Fallout 3 is an admirable achievement for Bethesda. It’s a game that provides action, adventure, exploration, interaction and excitement in a beautifully realised Armageddon that provides so many unexpected moments, but somehow manages to remain consistent and believable.

reviewText: Amazing game, I originally played this on the PS3 when it first came out. Was pretty good but graphics sucked because I was broke at the time and playing it on a 19 inch CRT (like the ones you used to have in your bedroom in the 90's). Then get a good solid uninterupted weekend, Lots of nice cold water and some snacks. And just sit there and play the crap out of it for that awsome weekend. It's that type of game.

reviewText:
I am going to start this review with controversy. Of the Fallout series I think Fallout 3 is the best of them. Now before you start flaming me over the fact your prefer Fallout: New Vegas or Fallout 1 for instance, let me try and explain this.

Fallout 1 & 2 remain good classics, that must be played by any fan of the later Fallouts, if only for the feel of it for the moment. The first Fallouts had the best incentive to go away from the safety of community, because either your vault or your tribe was in danger - both of them showing much of Fallout world. However, that said although I enjoy pixelated games... they are pixalated games and some of the tactic options are for the time excellent, but now outdated.

Fallout 3's incentive to travel is a bit odd. You must basically because you are thrown out and you are supposed to set out on your family member that walked out on you (before you go 'What?!', sorry I won't spoil more). This incentive is rather... odd. However, than comes Fallout 3 itself. Although opinions aside about the radio jockey - a controversy in the community - the added old school music and now stunning graphics make the Fallout world come to live. Although some errors in cannon can be found, most quests are excellent and tie into the world itself. Also allowing free roaming like the old game, but now the road itself is just as interresting - something Fallout 1 & 2 were less able do due to technical reasons (random encounters based on luck (or unluck)).

The main quest can be ended in much shorter time than I played in it, heck I have several lives, but I also have but one expansion. Still if you focus on only the mainquest than you are doing it wrong. Go out and explore and feel like an adventurer in a dismal post-apocolyptic world.

Personal Rating: Loved it.
Classic Rating: ★★★★★

I rushed a bit on finale because I wanted to see how it would end, but enjoyed most of its side quests and explored almost every inch of the places I traveled to.

The post-apocalyptic atmosphere and OST[archive.org] are amazing, you are free to behave the way you like (and take its consequences), explore the wasteland as much as you like and become the lone wanderer.

Played on Windows Seven x64 without too many problems, only some random crashes here and there - this guide covers all of the possible issues and proposes a solution for every one of them.

Would play it again and I feel like recommending it 100%.

reviewText:
If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding cheese cake recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1 cup digestive plain sweet biscuit crumbs
3 tablespoons sugar
3 tablespoons melted butter
40 ounces softened cream cheese
1 cup sugar
3 tablespoons flour
1 tablespoon vanilla
1 cup sour cream
4 eggs

Directions:
For The base:.
If you're using a dark pan, preheat the oven to 350. If you are using a shiny pan, 375.
Combine the crumbs, melted butter and 3 tbsp sugar well and pat onto the bottom of a 9 inch springform pan. I also like to very very lightly butter the sides of the pan so that the cheesecake will not stick later on.
Bake for 10 mins in your preheated oven and remove. Let it cool while you prepare your batter.
For the batter:.
Make sure everything is at room temperature.
Combine sugar, cheese, flour and vanilla in a big bowl and mix on medium speed till well combined. Don't forget to scrape the bowl as you're doing this.
Mix in the sour cream till its incorporated well. Then, add the eggs one by one, mixing well after each addition.
Pour the batter into the springform and let it bake for 1 hour and 10 minutes After the baking time, turn off the oven and leave the door ajar. Let the cake cool in there for about 1 1/2 hours.
Remove the cake and let it cool thoroughly. Refrigerate overnight.
Release the sides of the springform.
Eat.

reviewText: A wonderful game - given 9/10 almost perfect. I found this game to very enjoyable. Unlike many of our games today. This one felt much more immersive. Despite having older graphics and sometimes glitchy gameplay. The story and moral choices are touching and make you almost geninually care about finding your dad. Gameplay wise it is very well rounded. Unlike Fallout NV combat is much more simple. Seeing as how there is simply one type of ammo. Then you shoot said ammo. Nothing else. But NV boasted more guns and more mods for guns. But if you want a much better made game Fallout 3 is probably a better choice. It really works well on immersion. It lacks the painful abundance of loading screens in NV. While the wasteland around you almost feels fearful. Seeing as how you can run into raiders/mutants/dogs/bears/and basiclly anything else. If you are looking for a memorable game. This is probably it. HOWEVER one problem I noticed was that there was a point that one will reach in the game. Where finding supplies become basiclly an after thought. Seeing as how I soon had stocked up 400+ rare" MC cells. This impairs it but not totally killing it. If you had to buy either NV or 3. Choose 3 <----------- half loaf 3 confirmed"

reviewText: This game is easily one of my favorite games of all time, just everything about it I love. Bethesda really nails the whole post-apocalyptic feeling, because everything just feels empty and deserted. These days the game looks pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥ and even back in 2008 when I first played this game, I didn't think it looked that impressive (Dem Mods though). I admit that I'm a little spoiled by New Vegas, so the mechanics in FO3 don't feel quite as good as they do in New Vegas, but using VATS and the gameplay itself is excellent. I enjoyed all the songs in the game, but I really wish they would have added more, especially with all the DLC this game has. The karma system is something I feel all RPG's should have and while some of the decisions you make don't really affect things as a whole, it's still nice to have multiple choices to the quests you do. Audio as a whole is excellent (as stated with the music) but it just feels limited with the amount of the voice actors and the songs on the radio, the quality is definitely there though. I honestly could keep going on why I love this game so much and there is a lot of stuff I haven't even seen yet (DLC and Mods) but there is one big issue that makes me question this version in particular. On Windows 7, this game would crash at least every hour for me and sometimes it would be even worse. You would think with a game as popular as FO3, that Bethesda would at least fix something as big as this is, but they haven't. I have played this on Xbox 360 before and it maybe crashed 1 or 2 times (it's pretty sad when the console version of your game, performs better than the far superior PC). If you can deal with the technical issues, then you're in for one of the best RPG's of all time, up there with games like Mass Effect 2, Dragon Age: Origins, Skyrim, and KOTOR. Regardless of any of the negative things I said about FO3, I think one of the most important aspects of any game is fun and if I can sit and enjoy a game for extended play sessions for weeks and keep coming back to it after I already beat it before, well I think that's what every game should strive for.\n10/10 A Masterpiece

reviewText: (Don't focus too much on the negative reviews because it's mainly about a number of people that don't know how to search up a simple tutorial or a guide on how to fix the optimization issue)\n\nThe main reason why I started to play Fallout 3 is because of hype for Fallout 4. I'm waiting for so long and it's getting on my nerves quite frankly. But, at some time when I was playing, this idea got off of my mind and I actually had one of the most fun that I ever had during my playtime. The gameplay feels right, the pip-boy is a great feature, the soundtrack and the music has to be one of the best to date, and the story is amazing. If you like RPGs and open-world games, this is totally a must buy. But the debate comes upon everyone every once in a while about, which Fallout game is better. Fallout New Vegas or Fallout 3? Well, I couldn't decide so I just bought both of them. But if you want to look at the open world aspect and the terrain, Fallout 3 is a lot better. The empty wasteland of Fallout New Vegas just seemed a little boring, only seeing something interesting in your path every now and again. It might be a little trouble first playing it because of the compatibilitie issues, but once you've fixed that, you'll have fun. PS: What are you doing reading my review?! Go play Fallout 4 right now!

reviewText:
FALLOUT 3 GAME REVIEW

Introduction
When I was younger, I played this game on XBOX (those were dark days) and failed to even reach megaton (The first place you come to in the open world after what is essentially a tutorial level). Got fallout new vegas on steam soon after I got a gaming PC. I loved it. I loved skyrim too so i decided to replay fallout 3 to see if i was just an idiot when i was younger. SPOILER. i was.

It has a few issues with windows 7, and multiple monitors but more or less all bug fixes can be found here[pcgamingwiki.com]. nexus mod manager has loads of bug fixes and graphical upgrades for those who wan't them. If you are just interested in how good I thing this game is, and not why it is, then skip to the conclusion. but i urge you to read the whole thing to make up your own mind

Negatives
Here are a few things that are wrong with this game.

1.No Patch or bug fix for windows 7
this game has been about for ages. but it refuses to work with modern operating systems. bethesda could get so many more sales if they just released a patch. they could just release some user created patch's as an update. it wouldn't even take much time or money. This is (in my opinion) their best game and its going into a state of ruin. if the modding community was not there to support it. it wouldn't even be playable.

2.Games for windows live
Ok so it's not as bad as uplay or god forbid, origin, but its still irritating. not to mention the fact that it has cause numorous bugs and save corruptions/wipes in many games. many games now are having this tumor surgically removed but not this one. you can patch it out using mods and nexus mod manager but this should have been done as a patch by bethesda. Again, bethesda's best game is being dragged down by the lack of a simple patch, that not only would increase the sales and plays of the game but be cheap and cost virtually no time at all.

3.When  Your father dies
so your dad has this big project that is called project purity and it basically produces purified water from dirty water. and these bad guys called the enclave want it so they can infect it with a virus and wipe out all humans and other species who have even slightly mutated  since the war 200 years ago. and at the controll panel they ask your dad to activate it so he locks the door and floods it with radiation. one question. WHY???. at this point in the game i had full power armor (T51-B arguably the best model in the game) and ton of alien weaponry (from motehrship zeta). and he only killed some general guy and a foot soldier. i killed more men just getting here! his death was unneccisary and it really feels like its shoe-horned in to give the player a reason to hate the enclave.

4.The ending
The ending is complete rubbish. you have a choice to sacrifice yourself or tell either your mutant side-kick (if you have him) who won't actually die or some random brotherhood of steel woman to sacrifice themselves instead. i have a number of problems with this, the first being that if you chose to let them die, you die anyway, with no explination. the game simpley fades away and starts narating your life and all the stuff you have done. no explination given at all. its like they just ran out of time and said well people will only choose to sacrifice themselves right? ... right? ... RIGHT?". not to mention the fact taht you only die because you need to enter the room your dad filled with radiation for no good reason!  THIS MAKES THE BROKEN STEEL DLC  PRETTY MUCH REQUIRED - thats all im saying without using spoilers  becasue it increases level cap and removes the crappy ending. as well as giving a flimsy explination as to why you 'died' even if you didn't sacrifice yourself.

Positives
But that's just the negatives
date:
here are some positives:

1.It is bethesda's best game
if you like skyrim. its that but with technology instead of magic and guns. lots and lots of guns.

2.It is scary.
not the jump scare kind of way. this game is atmospherically scary. when you are trekking through the abandoned
recommended:
dark gloomy subway tunnels hearing the muffeled movement of the ghoulified remains of humans all around you. it getts pretty tense. afetr a while of straight playing you become slightly desensitised to the fear. but it's really good while it lasts and if you get the point lookout DLC then it does (when you travel to point lookout anyway) become really scarry again.

3.The story is amazing
The story
voteText: is really good. it becomes really immersive and the choices you have to make are sometimes really moraly grey. for instance i had a choice between killing this man who was routed to the spot for decades
helpfulPercent: unable to move
votesHelpful:
with little conversation and immense boredom. while having his insides torn slowly from his body by a tree that had grown around him. or speeding up the recovery of the wasteland. and improving life for everyone. it was a really difficult choice but I had to choose improving everyones life over his.

4.World Design
the world is teeming with secrets and
votesTotal: while it may not be very large
votesFunny:
requires quite a lot of exploration to find everything. random encounters make thsi all the more intresting also.

Conclusion
In conclusion

reviewText:
Went on a quest to find my Dad, I ended up doing the following instead:
1) Saving a town from a guy who wanted to blow it up.
2) Told a kid his Dad was killed by giant ants.
3) Unleashed a bunch of Ghouls onto a group of rich ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s in a tower.
4) Restored the Lincoln Memorial.
5) Helped a radio station host.
6) Died about 373,902,852 times.
7) Spent about 10 hours going on a wild goose chase to find my Dad.
8) Watched my Dad die.
9) Gave a hobo purified water.
10) Gave everyone purified water.
11) Died after saving the Wasteland.
12) And so much more!

They say war never changes, well I think Fallout won't change either *glitches through wall* see?

reviewText: It kills me to do this, since I love this game to death, but if you're running Windows 7 or later, DO NOT BUY THIS GAME.  It's highly likely that the game will not work for you and will kill your dreams of nostalgic playing.\n\nEDIT: I'd like to add that I did try to fix the game, but after a couple hours of searching for a fix, tweaking settings here and there, and trying on a different PC to no avail, I gave up.  The game is great, but I don't believe it should be on Steam if a majority of modern computers are going to have trouble running it.

reviewText:
I thought i should rewrite my review, since my old one is.. well old, and horrible, so here we go! This game is probably the most unique game i've ever played, its a open world RPG much like The Elder Scrolls games, but Fallout has much more, such as radiation poisining, cripable limbs, better atmosphere and more realisim.

The story begins with your birth, and in a quick pace progresses to the most important moments of your childhood, such as the time you get your Pipboy 3000. You live in Vault 101, a place made to keep its citizens alive during the nuclear war that happened on the surface. But, Vault 101's doors never opened after the nuclear war. Everybody was to repopulate and die in Vault 101, nobody was to leave and nobody was to enter. But of course you got out because.. who would want to live in a scary vault filled with people for the rest of your life?

After your childhood dream" ends you are awakened by alarms

Played more than 75 hours, loved every minute of it. If you haven't bought this game yet and you have some money left, BUY it! Wow! wow! wow! wait! My second reason is that some mods do require all dlc's. I hope this will help people and that they don't buy the standard editon but the GOTY edition.

My rating for this game is: 9/10

reviewText:
TLDR VERDICTThough dated, Fallout 3s good writing and survivalist atmosphere more than makes up for the technical and visual issues. A good 100+ hour world to get lost in, and would recommend DLCs too.

FULL REVIEW BELOW
“Man had succeeded in destroying the world – but war, war never changes” – Ron Pearlman

The year is 2277 and it has been 200 years since the Great War that consumed the Earth in nuclear fire and radiation. You are a resident of Vault 101, one of many underground shelters built before the war. The door to Vault 101 slides open for the first time in 200 years, and you emerge into the ruins of Washington D.C, now known as The Capital Wasteland.

This review is written from the perspective of a fan of RPGs and story-driven games, who hasn’t played any other Fallout games.

GAMEPLAY AND DESIGNFallout 3 is a massive open world sandbox RPG that can be played from a first or third-person perspective. You are thrust into the world and given a goal, but it is up to you to decide how long you want to take to reach it. The Capital Wasteland is a harsh and sprawling land that lets you go wherever you want, whenever you want. The map is absolutely huge, consisting of downtown DC and all of its surrounding areas ranging from sewers to suburbs. The absolutely huge amount of approaches to the land can be overwhelming for some players. You may struggle with knowing where to start, especially given the fact the game offers very little direction. Just doing quests would probably only uncover a quarter to a third of the entire map, so players that prefer independent exploration and spontaneous discovery will get a lot of more value vs. someone who follows the quest markers.

The progression system is fair and you start to feel more powerful over the course of the game, however by the end if you play your stats right you can literally have a jack of all trades, master of all character. Being able to cap every single stat on one character can eliminate some replay ability meaning the only reason to start another character would be alternative morality choices. On the other hand, it does eliminate the annoying factor of not being able to see what’s behind that door because I’m one point too short in this specific stat for people who don’t have time for 5 different playthroughs. Enemy difficulty adapts to your character level rather than the areas. This means that no matter where you go, the enemies will always be at your level. This is good as it keeps the combat fresh and evolving all the way to the very end, but bad because you can't stomp early game areas. It also allows players to explore freely at any point in the game without the risk of being suddenly disintegrated by some level 30 mob and losing 3 hours of progress because you forgot to save.

I really like the way the game handles the exploration and looting systems. You can fast travel back to any area you’ve discovered. This sparks the age old argument of immersion vs. quality of life, but hey, you’re not forced to use it. As you work your way through the game you slowly progress from picking up as much useless crap as you can carry to analysing the environment and cherry picking the most relevant and valuable stuff. For example, I didn’t see the point in lugging around a motorcycle gas tank until I found out you can build a flaming sword out of them and began hunting for them. I hoarded seemingly useless scrap metal until it paid off because it turned out some guy in a city was willing to pay for it to fix some pipes. I felt a wasteland junk expert by the end, as my approach to every new room became systematically rummaging through filing cabinets and desks for valuables that extend beyond money vs. not money.

STORY AND NARRATIVEFallout 3s story is essentially structured into the main quest, side quests and DLC quests.  The main quest itself is a pretty mediocre story about finding your dad. It has its moments, but ultimately just serves to give the game a beginning and end. The middle portion, you will spend getting lost in the sometimes great, sometimes bad and sometimes plain weird side quests. The side quests are few in number (given the games size) and you won’t see 4 or 5 people with floating question marks on their heads asking you to fetch 12 bear asses. The role play aspect plays a big role in these side quests, allowing you to morally be the second coming of Christ, a boring stoic neutral dude, or Lucifer himself. This can cause quests to branch a few different ways (your stats can come into play during conversations too) but ultimately it usually ends up resulting to being good or evil. The excellent DLC packs definitely present a lot more ambiguous choices where you really have to think about things beyond being good or evil. Every DLC adds something to the game both story and gameplay wise, and I whole heartedly recommend getting them all (or the Ultimate Edition) if you can.

The other side of the story telling is more subtle than speaking to townsfolk and being explicitly told what’s going on. A lot of the locations in the game contain stories that you figure out, rather than being told. For example, I entered a motel room with a bunch of long dead skeletons, some guns and pre-war cash laying around. Some people would just loot the joint and move on, and that’s fine. Other people will look around and realise through the way the bodies and guns are positioned and seeing the pre-war money was leading back to a briefcase in the middle of the room, that a standoff after a bank heist took place in this room over 200 years ago. Bethesda put a lot of TLC and work into deliberately laying places out this way. It’s not just a random composition, there is a reason why everything is the way it is. You may think it’s a shame that so much work was put into things most players would miss, but I prefer the think that the fact that so many players miss it makes it much more special for the players that catch it.

The voiceover work can be a bit hit and miss, with the stand out performances being Ron Pearlman’s narration and Liam Neeson as your dad. Everything else is ok, or sometimes outright embarrassing, but I suppose that’s fair enough given the sheer amount of people there are to converse with. Your character isn’t voice acted, which of course gives a lot more freedom to the writers regarding conversation options. The writing is the real star of the show in this game. The game also offers a couple interesting radio stations to listen to whilst you roam the wastes, but in a game as long as this you will run into a lot of recurring dialogue and music that unfortunately gets old fast.

GRAPHICS AND PERFORAMANCEFallout 3 was released in 2008 and it shows. It is by no means an ugly game and the scale of the world definitely makes up for the lack of eye candy.  The scale of the world also results in lots and lots of bugs. Some can be game breaking (albeit rarely) and others are just irritating or sometimes humorous. Ultimately I would say it’s worth powering through them to play the game. The game also has some major stability issues, especially on newer hardware. For instance I was having issues because for some reason this game was having issues with an OS newer than Vista and a processor with more than two cores. Almost everyone falls under that blanket these days and although these have easy fixes they are still annoying to deal with. The game used to have GFWL but thankfully it’s been removed. I would normally mitigate the ugliness of older games with mods, but I had issues with those here as well. Your mileage may vary, but I couldn’t go over 8-10 mods without constant crashing and FPS drops. In depth complicated mods are also much more annoying to install than something like Skyrim so I had to settle for more minor visual and quality of life changes.
voteText: 11 of 14 people (79%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

Your character isn’t voice acted, which of course gives a lot more freedom to the writers regarding conversation options. The writing is the real star of the show in this game. The game also offers a couple interesting radio stations to listen to whilst you roam the wastes, but in a game as long as this you will run into a lot of recurring dialogue and music that unfortunately gets old fast.

GRAPHICS AND PERFORAMANCEFallout 3 was released in 2008 and it shows. It is by no means an ugly game and the scale of the world definitely makes up for the lack of eye candy.  The scale of the world also results in lots and lots of bugs. Some can be game breaking (albeit rarely) and others are just irritating or sometimes humorous. Ultimately I would say it’s worth powering through them to play the game. The game also has some major stability issues, especially on newer hardware. For instance I was having issues because for some reason this game was having issues with an OS newer than Vista and a processor with more than two cores. Almost everyone falls under that blanket these days and although these have easy fixes they are still annoying to deal with. The game used to have GFWL but thankfully it’s been removed. I would normally mitigate the ugliness of older games with mods, but I had issues with those here as well. Your mileage may vary, but I couldn’t go over 8-10 mods without constant crashing and FPS drops. In depth complicated mods are also much more annoying to install than something like Skyrim so I had to settle for more minor visual and quality of life changes.

reviewText: This is one of the greatest games I've ever played.  The game world is huge, and there are tons of places to explore and things to see.  It's hard to put into words how tightly the elements of character, setting, and plot are woven together.  Discovering what has happened to humanity after the nuclear apocalypse is fantastically entertaining.  The controls are very easy to get used to, and what first looks like a complex inventory\status menu turns out to be quite simple and logical once you get the hang of it.  The choices you make have observable consequences, and you will more than likely develop real feelings toward some of the characters you meet, unless your heart is made of stone.  Regardless, exploring post-apocalyptic DC is a fantastic experience I would recommend to anyone.\n\nI purchased the game and all DLC for $7.24 and have played around 63 hours as of this edit.  This is a 10/10 game for sure.

reviewText: Fallout 3 is one of the greatest games I have ever played it is most definetly on my 10 games of all time. Fallout 3 takes place in a desolate wasteland filled with anarchy and hatred but what makes it amazing are the glimmers of hope surrounding the otherwise hopeless landscape. Fallout 3 has great lore and interesting story that is immersive and not only is story engage but also the atmosphere. It makes you want to explore the Capital wasteland even more. The combat mechanics are a little meh, but you can get plenty of mods to fix that from the nexus. Speaking of mods the mods for this game are amazing which increases the experience 10 fold. So overall Fallout 3 is a priceless gem that should not be skipped, I would rate this 9.8/10. This game is amazing.

reviewText:
ENGLISH and Italian Review  Recensione Inglese ed ITALIANA

AWAY FROM HERE, BUY THE GAME OF THE YEAR EDITION!

VIA DI QUI, COMPRA LA GAME OF THE YEAR EDITION!


War... war never changes.

English:

Don't trust my gametime, i've bought this game on Steam too, just for collection. This game literally ruined my life, i've finished it like 14 times before losing the count. No, i'm not crazy, yes, my social life imploded. And don't trust the grandpas that will tell you this game is garbage just because they played the first 2 Fallouts and refused to play this one, they are just ignorant. In this game you live a wonderful and touching adventure in first person (Identifying so with the character), watching the character growing and becoming the hero or anti-hero that he'll be. Oh yes, because obviously you can and have to choose between choices that will influence the events and your karma. So, we have an abnormus replay factor, if we consider that we can play as good, bad, neutrals or do a mixed playtrough, choosing maybe a different type of class for the fight. AND, the game is easily moddable and has a large and active modding community: Nexus Mods. So, even if you have finished it in every way possible, you can mod it and transform it in a new game to discover. Trust me, this game is AWESOME.


La guerra... la guerra non cambia mai.

Italiano:

Non fidatevi del tempo di gioco che dice Steam, l'ho comprato anche qui giusto per averlo. Questo gioco ha letteralmente rovinato la mia vita, lo avrò finito qualcosa come 14 volte prima di perdere il conto. No, non sono pazzo, si, la mia vita sociale ne ha risentito un pochino. E non fidatevi dei vecchiacci che vi diranno che questo titolo fa schifo, solo perché giocarono ai primi due ai tempi, e si rifiutarono di giocare questo, sono degli ignoranti. In questo gioco vivi un'avventura stupenda e toccante in prima persona (Immedesimandoti dunque nel personaggio), vedendo il personaggio crescere man mano e plasmandolo lentamente nell'eroe o antieroe che sarà. Eh si, perché ovviamente potrai e dovrai fare delle scelte che influenzeranno gli eventi ed il tuo karma. Abbiamo dunque anche un fattore rigiocabilità enorme se consideriamo che possiamo giocare da cattivi, da buoni, da neutri o fare un mix, scegliendo magari anche una tipologia di personaggio diversa per quanto riguarda i combattimenti. Senza contare il fatto che il gioco è facilmente moddabile e vanta di una community di modders vasta e attiva, ovvero Nexus Mods. Dunque anche avendolo finito in tutte le maniere possibili e immaginabili, potete ancora moddarlo all'infinito e renderlo un gioco nuovo tutto da riscoprire. Fidatevi, questo gioco è perfetto.

reviewText:
If you search a game to feel lying in a post-nuclear, chaotic and anarchic world, this game is yours. Or if you want an Oblivion or Skyrim with fire weapons, this game is yours too. Although the map isn't as big as Skyirm, it was a big one when it was released, and it has a lot of details that makes worth to spend time exploring it all.

The history is great, and not only this major one. There are little histories inside the big one, details or personal messages of past wastelanders that immerses you even more inside the wasteland.

The characters are great too.You can find evil persons, good persons, weird ones, etc... the world is still alive.  Dialogues are great and there many ways to bring a conversation. Also it has benefits if you choose certain options, so it's interesting to repeat to see how many possibilites are there.

Also has dark humour and easter eggs. It's an open world, so you don't have to go just by one way, you can go wherever you want.

The only bad thing i would say is that maybe there isn't much variety of weapons, specially on the melee field. Also the karma system is a little overbalanced, it's hard to be evil. Also, the level cap its at 20, but that is solved if you buy the DLC Broken Steel, which raises it to 30.

9/10

reviewText: I don't care what most people say - this game is so much better than New Vegas (not that I mind New Vegas all that much either). Why is it so much better? It's so creatively done; everything has this humorous quality to it; there are quaint little extra touches to be found everywhere. It's just so gloriously satisfying to be immersed in this world that has been so painstakingly put together just for your entertainment.\nThe amusing little side stories that you uncover in this game can be quite hilarious (if you are anything at all like me then you can't stop yourself from snooping every email on every working terminal you happen to pass by). The characters can be so amusingly ridiculous at times that you just want to shoot them or worse yet set them loose in the desert to see how badly they fare. And some of the missions are just... Well, completely surprising. They can leave you scratching your head and wondering what the hell you should do, which way should you go? And I really love that! I never thought a game could be like that. And yet this one is. It will always be my absolute favourite.

reviewText:
I really really really don't want to do this but I gotta give it thumbs down.
Don't get me wrong I love the Bethesda games, especially the old ones but really? Not working on Win 7 and 8? No excuse. Most people use Win 7 and it was released only a year before Win 7. So if Bethesda wanted Fallout 3 to have a shelf life of more than one year, they should have patched it.
Yes there are fixes and workarounds but they only work occasionally and are frequently too complex for a dumbass like me (a dumbass who would buy a game that doesn't work with his OS).

Which brings us to two questions.

1) Why has this not been patched?

2) Why is it on Steam if most people can not play it?

And I am pretty sure that there is one answer for both questions; Money and Laziness". Unfortunate as this and ESO have made me start to wonder
date:
3) Is Bethesda going to start being like EA (and by "EA" I mean "Cashcowing and not fixing problems and releasing low quality games")?

And I think that the answer is a sad "Yes." And I think it has for some time.

The game is decent though."

reviewText: Personally this is my favourite game in the Fallout series as it covers and explains everything about the storyline. Sadly though i wasnt able to experience the second game of the franchise. I rarely found any bugs or glitches with this game and has replayability since you are always trying to discover new locations, characters, or enemies and go back and find little secrets hidden within the game or just to simply find things you havnt seen since you last played. Although even with this ther can tend to be small tiny glitches such as main characters your supposed to follow getting stuck in walls which makes you have to start from your recent save, but this rarely happens anyway. Even when you complete the storyline you can still explore these wastelands to find new side quest which are generally killing someone or just getting specific items. Bethesda really did a good job at making this brilliant game, Personally i would rate it 8/10 and would recommend it.

reviewText:
Good day once again close friends and strangers of the vast and dangerous internets, I have returned for another review. This time, of Fallout 3. Shall we get started?

To start, I have to say I don't think I've ever experienced a more enjoyable character customisation than the one found in this game. It was full of humour and interesting choices (and said interesting choices often lead to more humour) and this theme continues throughout the duration of the game. Some notable choices include the chace to explode one of the only decent cities in the game, and the opportunity to commit genocide (that's going to remain without context; I don't want to spoil it for you). I honestly can't wait to jump back in and get back to making choices. CHOICES!!!!!!

There's plenty of content in this game. In most of my reviews I mention that there's a need for extra content, or so much of the same type of content that it got stale but, much like the story of goldilocks, this bed was just right (How can a bed be too soft?!) I liked how the game was riddled with locked doors that could only be opened if you had a certain science or lock picking skill

The storyline was admirable, but not incredible. It basically consisted of You're dad's gone missing
date: go find 'im" and then turns into "Genocide

reviewText:
After finally finishing Fallout 3 (which my hours aren't actually recorded on Steam which annoys me), I feel like now I can finally write a review about how I feel for this game:

In the beginning, I felt like I was going to get bored of this game cause I didn't enjoy the Vault 101 part a lot. But after a while, I enjoyed the game a lot.

The game's difficult, it has a nice atmosphere, the story's great and the characters are pretty good in terms of personality. Hell, I even got scared sh*tless when I was encountering some enemies in the night and inside some buildings.

However, I do think that the main story was a bit short but I found it enjoyable nonetheless. I get it that you can continue your story with the Broken Steel DLC but I don't really have it, that's why it was short for me. And as for the notice, yes. It's not optimized for Windows 7 and later since it wasn't working at the beginning, but after watching a guide of how to make it work on Youtube, it took me like a few minutes to make it work. Not a very big deal.

Overall, Fallout 3 is not my favorite Fallout game but it's surely one of my favorite games. I can fully recommend this game. And if you have a potato PC like I do, then don't worry. The game was running with like 30 FPS and I had a nice time.

P.S.: That f*cking behemoth in the beginning, though. I wasn't expecting that at all. ;-; Also, I can't believe there's a weapon called Fat man" lol."

reviewText: While nothing at all like the original Fallout games, I'm glad it didn't try to be. Bethesda took the route of making their own game set in the Fallout universe, and it paid off in spades.\n\nThe Capitol Wasteland is one of my favourite settings in any open-world game yet. If you want a good Western RPG check it out. While New Vegas is more robust, Fallout 3 has a more concise story, and a much more fleshed out world to explore.

reviewText:
Alot of people call this game Elder Scrolls with Guns.... and sure that may be close to true, but i would say this is different enough to stand without being categorized as such. the game play mechanics are very different here. The pacing of the story is much different.and there is V.A.T.S. which there is nothing even close to similar in either of the Elder Scrolls games.
This games only drawback is GFWL, and some win 7 machines don't like to run the game well. I personally didn't have any issues with it however.

This game is on my list of top favorite games of all time, at least in the top 10 for sure. It has it all. Good graphics, a gripping story, terrific game play, almost infinite reputability. it is very well worth the price, even with its very few shortcomings.

reviewText:
(contains spoilers)
when i first played fallout 3, i played for an entire weekend. sure it has bugs and quirks, but it's engrossing and immersive. and sure, i could patch it to fix the bugs, but in the hundred or more hours i've played it (not just on steam) i couldn't be bothered. this is one game which allows you to do the following things (spoilers): go on a peyote trip to infiltrate a cult, and subsequently settle a 200 year old blood feud between a mutated congressman and a disembodied brain. get abducted by aliens and violently commandeer their ship with the help of a 70 year old child, a cowboy, a samurai, a US army medic, and one dead astrnaut. break your legs and irradiate yourself... for SCIENCE! lead a communist rebellion that goes about exactly the way of the trotskyites'. enter into the simulation of an idyllic 50's picket fence neighborhood and torture people at the behest of a mad scientist disguised as a little girl. helping Liam Neeson water the collective lawns of every dead person in the united states, and during all of this, i honestly couldn't tell you where anything had changed along the ride, because i was still systematically painting walls red with an arsenal of weapons just varied enough to be interesting, and not so varied as to bog itself down.
is it perfect? no, not even close. but the full DLC pack is $20 on steam and i guaruntee you will never get the same amount of joy for 20 bucks at an arcade,
even a Live Arcade
in a Box
wit an X" on it
rudding buy this thing! it will ruin your life for the better."

reviewText:
First Thoughts
This game looks a little weird"(=)
"The art style and direction is pretty awesome though"(+)
"Lots of easily added mods"(+)
"Atmosphere is amazing!"(+)
"What day is it...?"(+++)

Review
Fallout 3 has to be one of the best Open World RPGs I've ever played and has to be one of my favorite games. Now I know what you're thinking and before you say anything about how long I've played
date: but I owned the game on xbox before rebuying it because it's just that great of a game. This game has one of the best post apocolyptic setting and style I've ever seen.The game play is obviously like any RPG made by Bethesda. You can really get a feel for your character and have relativly nice control over who they are
recommended: even if it's all put on a morality system that sometimes can be a little off. The situations you're put into have multiple outcomes and ways of going about them and the game gives you a sizeable amount of freedom without giving you everything. The combat and weapon variety is awesome
hoursPlayed: even if some weapons are better than others. If you are really committed to having your character be a certain way
voteText: you have all the freedom to do it and the tools available. It really is a game where you can get a feel for how you want to do something. And the large modding community this game had gives this game even more replay value because mods can add so much more to this game.\nNow there will always be obvious problems in these games. While the game is mostly great
helpfulPercent: you will experience your occasional bug but that is pretty standard with Bethesda RPGs. And the fact that when you try and zoom in with a weapon
votesHelpful: it just ZOOMS in was a pretty bad choice(which I'm glad can be fixed with mods and that Bethesda later chose to change for Fallout: NV). Also that third person was also a little weird. While I'm sure some people may have enjoyed it
votesTotal: I usually stayed with first person. I think this could've been fixed if you had more control over where your character was located(I.E. To the right
votesFunny: left or centered). The game is also EXTREMELY easy if you're a thief. You actually have to force yourself into not being successful because it's too easy to be successful in this game.\n\nBut all and all
commentsCount: I recommend this game to EVERYONE who even has a slight interest in trying it because it's an experience that isn't worth missing out on.  Also get The Pitt. BEST DLC FOR THIS GAME EVVVVVEEEEERRRRR\n\nFinal Verdict: 9.5/10"

Combat in Fallout 3 is very satisfying

Fallout 3 does not support Multiplayer.

Sidequests are very enjoyable

reviewText:
This game is one of the best fps/rpg I have ever played it was a huge change from the old fallouts made back in the late 90's and it brought a lot more to the wasteland than ever before it has a very lage world that you are open to explore right from the start of the game it has many side quests that you could get lost in and even forget about the main quest line. reviewText:
Fallout 3 is a sandbox RPG from the people who brought you Oblivion, and like Oblivion, it has ups and downs. The ups are decent graphics, good balance and gameplay, decent voice acting and quests, while the downs are crashes and graphical errors, horrible animations, weak level perks, and to be honest? Not much replayability. Yeah you can choose different outcomes for quests, or wield different weapons, but attention isn't given enough to the different styles (melee, ranged, unarmed) to warrant playing out different characters.

But this is just my opinion. I still say this is a fantastic game despite its flaws, and worth buying. The encounters, both scripted and unscripted, are fun, plain and simple. There's plenty to explore and amusing scenarios to play over and over quickly via the quicksave and quickload, which is instant, unlike other games. The AI is decent, funny, and makes for interesting scenarios.

As a standalone game it's worth the investment, just dont expect perfection. 8/10

reviewText: Except with the downside of it not being compatible with Windows 8 it is possibly one of the best games of all time. New Vegas may have polished what Fallout 3 lacked but Fallout 3 has such a different and unique atmosphere from NV. I will not give any spoilers as to what happens during the game in this review so don't worry. The game really does capture you from the start and transport you all the way to the end which is amazingly well done. You will begin to feel for the characters that you encounter and if they so happen to die you'll actually care unlike some other games. The gameplay is obviously from a FPS perspective and it is an new feature added that wasn't in the previous games. The open world element to the game is suited to the game and exploration is encouraged throughout it. The graphics may seem slightly dated but that is hardly noticable when you immerse yourself in this expansive world of post-apocalyptic Washington DC. Overall I give this game a 8.5/10 an amazing game that revived the franchise.

reviewText: This RPG is so great I bought it on every console, a retail PC copy and a steam copy. Played it for at least 1000 hours combined. beat it at least 10 times. Great narrative, but the DLC don't add much to the storry. The storry lasts 2 hours if you don't do side quests and fast travel a lot.\nGood graphics on the console, for its age, also a ton of graphical mods to improve the PC version. A huge modding community at nexus, the game features porn mods, halo mods, even a multiplayer mod.\nMy only real complaint is 100mb save files. So for people who like having man saved games this is huge. I have 10GB in saves.

reviewText:
Amazing game. It is one of the best I have played. I prefer it to New Vegas as the humour is much better. New Vegas seemed to have a very depressing tone to it while this does not.

Steam says I have about 125 hours out of it. I easily have tripple. Steam hasn't clocked alot of my hours as I have launched the game in a different way which steam doesn't register. This is because there are hundreds of mods available which are easy to install. Modding the game is also easy.

Lots of people reccomed this game because of VATS. I never use VATS as I think it takes away some of the FPS part of it. But it's there and does look pretty cool if you use it.

The game in a whole is genius. The 50s twist to a game set roughly 250 years into the future from now really is unique and really makes the game's theme something special.

reviewText:
Fallout 3 is my favourite video game of all time!

one of the things Fallout 3 does right is it´s incredibley depressing and hopeless atmosphere you feel like all hope is lost at the beginning but once you help you father to fufill his work on Project Purity things feel better! because of you!!

Locations... Characters is something Fallout 3 does almost flawlessly... they iconic location such as the washington monument and the lincoln memorial are so well re-created in this depressing post-apocalyptic setting!!! not to mention the characters are very well done by Bethesda.. my favourite companion in any Fallout game is Fawkes he is so ♥♥♥♥ing awesome!!!! i can´t stress it enough if your doing a playthrough of Fallout 3! use him...

The DLC´s
funny to think that my main gripe with Fallout 3 isn´t even part of the main game!!!!! Mothership Zeta is the worst DLC of all Fallout games to date imo it is unitresting and boring! Point Lookout on the other hand is completely different! it has intresting characters... creppy locations and a fairly good main quest! overall i recommend it the other DLC´s Broken Steel is basically a must have if your serious about this game as it lifts the level cap from 20 to 30 aswell as let´s you play after the game´s ending The Pitt is also a pretty good DLC and i recommend it aswell!

Verdict
with everything i said in this review there is still so much more that is great about Fallout 3! sure i´m not gonna deny that it´s buggy and is not optimized for Windows 7 and up tho there are work arounds.... besides that Fallout 3 is easily my favourite video game of all time!!!!!

reviewText: Where do i start? First of all, Its fallout, These games are known for their action-packed, yet emotionally and path focused stories. First of all I'll adress negatives; The game is VERY dark. (this isnt a negative for all people, but for me it is, I like bright colorful scenes, with a more realistic story) Another negative is well, Later on in the story there isnt VERY much to do, although you'll find quests what bothers me is, you'll find a city with 50+ and only 1 or 2 people will give you something to do. Another thing is the ♥♥♥♥ING ACCURACY IN VATS IS AWFUL, IVE BEEN FACE FIRST WITH OVER 500 MOBS WITH A .44 REPEATER ONLY TO MISS, JESUS CHRIST. And lastly in my Cons is Optimization. some people have it worse some people have it ok, luckily i was the Ok side. The game crashes every 4 or so hours and alt-tabbing means you have to restart the entire game. Also controller support is god awful, (THE GAME HAS GWOL CAREFUL!!!)\nWhere do I start with the good? Jesus christ man this game, the story is godly, the dialouge options are amazing not to mention the way the ending is molded based on your choices. You'll have follows based on karma, exclusive rewards for doing good or bad deeds, it just never ends. The guns go on and on, combat is actually fun, your limbs get crippled and the game is realistic. It isnt some COD ♥♥♥♥ where i find ammo on every body i see, I literally need to scavenge and use my rarer rounds (.44, 308 etc) wisley and dont find them off little timmy's body. Not to mention the atmosphere (although i hate dark games) goes INCREDIBLEY WELL. The games characters and factions even put into a proper perspective what happens in such an enviorment, although ill end my review here, please, pick up this game either on a console or a PC (optimization on PC is ♥♥♥♥) but play it, just play it.

reviewText:
WARNING THIS REVIEW MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS Fallout 3 has to be in my top 5 games of all time, It has such a amazing story and gameplay. Huge variety of weapons and the map is massive, You will never run out of missions or places to explore. Basicly you wonder a awesome wasteland listening to great 30's and 40's music. Starting with old wornout rifles and revolvers working your way up to lazer rifles and plasma casters, And starting with old dusty coats and a jumpsuit from when you were in a vault to beast power armor 'Some with tesla coils on them'... There is so many ways to play this game. You could be a good Samaritan and help everybody out and people would recognize that.. Or you could be the opposite of that and not help people.. Kill innocent's. and people would recognize that also.

Overall score:
Story ~ 9/10 'Will keep you interested, Alot of thought'
Graphics ~ 6.5/10 'They aren't bad just nothing to brag about'
Physics ~ 5/10 'Just your average grade, You can pick up items though'
Replayability ~ 10/10 'I could play this game again no questions asked, I've finished it probably 10 times'

p.s. Liam Neeson is your father

reviewText:
It's the year 2277 and bombs have fallen. You live in an underground vault, what seems to be very peaceful; until your dad decides to leave, and chaos breaks out. You follow him and end up in a completely destroyed wasteland where you will meet all sorts of amazing and terrifying things, while trying to find your dad.

You can explore the wasteland in either third person or first person. There's a special V.A.T.S. (Vault-Tec Assisted Targeting System) available to target specific body parts. It then shows a slow-motion scene of you dismembering the abominations you meet in the most gruesome way, which makes combat extremely fun and satisfying.

Options are endless. You can spend hours exploring the destroyed buildings you come across, or search for loot in dark caverns, or just help someone out who's in trouble; it's all up to you. Meanwhile, you'll earn experience, improve skills and gain perks, which helps you build your ultimate character. You can be a saint, or the devil himself, or choose the middle road. People will react differently and dialogue differs according to your playing style.

Everything is well written and the dialogue can be very interesting, serious, or just plain hilarious at times. Often you will find yourself grinning at the hilarious things people say or things that happen.

Graphically, this game isn't exactly stunning; character models often look a bit 'stiff' and dated, but the atmosphere and general details totally make up for that. Audiovisual this game is incredible. You hear happy classical tunes coming from your radio in the background, while in reality everything around you is destroyed and not happy at all. And although you will probably hear the same lines every now and then, voice-acting is well done.

The game itself has a lot of bugs, glitches and flaws, but if you look past it, you will see a beautiful game with an overwhelming amount of content, good for literally hunderds upon hundreds of playing hours. The gameplay is very addictive, this is roleplaying at its finest. It will draw you in, and once you've got the grasp of it, it's difficult to let go. You want to keep exploring, discover new places, quests, and persons. Everytime you play, you're bound to find something new. Simply a masterful game that's worth every penny and a must play for anyone.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Fallout 3 was a great game when it was new, and thanks to the power of mods, this game is just as good today (2015). Mods have updated the visuals, effects, and content of the game to feel like it's brand new.

Everywhere you go, there is a town or person that needs to be saved, and you are that person who can save everyone... or not. While this game doesn't offer as much freedom of choice that New Vegas offers, Fallout 3 gives you many opportunities to feel like a hero in various ways.

Newer games tend to throw side-quests at you so you can get detoured for hours doing a lot of them. Fallout 3's story progresses in a very linear fashion, and while there are many sidequests that you can partake in, you often have to go out of your way to find and solve these quests. You can very realistically go from the beginning to end of this game without doing one sidequest. It's not a bad thing, but it does make this game less immersive than more recent games of this type.

If you've never played Fallout 3 before, this is definitely one worth playing as it set the bar for other amazing games in the genre.

8/10 Great""

reviewText: If you are buying this game, it means that you are getting ready for fallout 4 just like the rest of us. To start this review off you should know that I have put a good amount of hours in the game, but since its not made for windows 10, I had to troubleshoot in order to get the game running and one of the cons to that is that it does not show how many hours you have put into the game. Overall the game is OK for something that came out in 2008, It is essentially skyrim, with mutants, and not dragons. the gameplay is alright, you still can't sprint (Just like Skyrim) so thats a bit of a problem, but so far the storyline is cool, the characters, and the open world is really cool. If you have never played any of the fallout games, and you still want to get fallout 4, I would suggest, playing Fallout 3 just to get yourself familliar on whats to come.\n\nOVerall the game is good, especially if you can get it on sale, but like the game says, it is not compadable for windows 10 so you will have to do a bit of searching to get it running, but for me it took less then 5 minutes to get it started.

reviewText:
Fallout 3, a game I adored since I knew this game was made by Bethesda. The gameplay is much like The Elder Scrolls with guns. It's like playing Oblivion but in a post-apocalyptic era. Taking the role of a father's son you embark on a journey escaping from your home, Vault 101. You never knew what is going on in the outside world until you see that the world is already ruined. There are tons of side missions to do, but never had the time to finish it all. The best thing is, it's an open world RPG game. The story is immersive and driven well within the game and has choices, choices, choices. Choices which leads to your own responsibilities. This is truly a great game even when it's quite old now. I hope that there will be a remake for Fallout soon.
Story: 9/10 - Good story, yet needs more depth. Otherwise, it has a very good story in it.
Difficulty: 8/10 - Great, quite challenging in my opinion for a post-apocalyptic survival game. Yet it can be cheated by console commands. Money is also crucial and buying things are expensive so it truly sets the environment well.
Quests: 8/10 - The quests are great, lots of them. But some of them might be boring or yet too easy.
Gameplay: 9/10 - Hours of gameplay in an open world game made this game interesting. (Not counting the DLCs yet)
Game Flow: 8.5/10 - Good, except there are a few bugs lying around here and there such as quests that didn't trigger, glitches that make you suddenly fall into a bottomless world, etc.

Overall 8.5/10 - What more can you expect?

reviewText:
A fantastic game, full of wonderful explorations and fun. The game should be played with mods though, to fix various problems; refresh the look of the world and so on.

The game always felt like it provided something new at each corner. I loved building my own weapons and exploring the wasteland with my companions.

The sound work though is rather stale at places, which makes the enjoyment less enjoyable for audiophiles. The music is by all the great artists in the past, who makes killing people so enjoyable in the sweet tunes of classics.

The voice acting is great, though voices are often reused for new characters.
It is good to hear Paul Eiding's voice, even though he only play old characters.

Overall, it is a long game and you need to explore alittle to fully enjoy fallout 3.

Highly recommended for the wastelanders.

reviewText:
What would happpen if the pre-modern times cold war went full-on hot? Fallout 3, minus any survivors of course. This game has such a unique setting and characters that it's hard to compare with any other title, however, it has its own flaws.

Pros:

-Good story.
-Excellent character acting, for an open world that is.
-Incredibly well detailed open world. I think that the world looks like as if every meter of it is unique.
-Hours of fun.

Cons:

-Terrible ending, I mean, I do get the ending cinematics, but why would anyone make a game so rich in content and incredibly well detailed scenery and not let the player explore this after the main quest end? I managed to explore only about 30% of the game world before I remembered the ending sucks. And I sure ain't planning on replaying this for the 3rd time.

reviewText: Quite possibly the best RPG ever made; Fallout 3 does what other sandbox RPG games attempt to do; create an enormous open world mixed with an immersive story and interesting characters. Decided to be good or bad, the world is filled with interesting quests that wont let you stop playing. The biggest draw is exploration; how Washington DC looks after a large scale nuclear war, visiting new markers on your map and fighting off enemies or helping random civilians. I was skeptical at first, Fallout 3 takes a bit to get going, but once youre committed Fallout 3 will not disappoint. I promise you that.

reviewText: The fact that so many people still name Fallout 3 as “the greatest or most significant or best” Fallout game ever only tells you how far Fallout still is from becoming a serious series. FPS critics have long recognized that the most influential FPS games of all times are Doom and Wolfensteinwho were not the most famous or best sellers of their times, let alone of all times. Adventure critics rank the highly controversial Legend of Zelda over games such as Monkeys Island who were highly popular in online communities. Fallout critics are still blinded by commercial success. Fallout 3 sold more than anyone else (not true, by the way), therefore it must have been the greatest. RPG critics grew up playing a lot of RPG games of the past, adventure critics grew up playing a lot of adventure games of the past. Fallout critics are often totally ignorant of the Fallout games of the past, they barely know the originals. No wonder they will think that Bethesda did anything worthy of being saved. In a sense, Fallout 3 is emblematic of the status of RPG criticism as a whole: too much attention paid to commercial phenomena (be it Bethesda or whomever else) and too little to the merits of real games. If somebody creates the most divine game but no major publisher picks him up and sells him around the world, a lot of RPG critics will ignore him. If a major publisher picks up a company who is as stereotyped as can be but launches them worldwide, your average critic will waste rivers of ink on her or him. This is the sad status of RPG criticism: RPG critics are basically publicists working for major publishers, distributors and game stores. They simply highlight what product the gaming business wants to make money from. Hopefully, one not-too-distant day, there will be a clear demarcation between a great RPG like Baldur's Gate, which never sold much, unlike commercial products like Fallout 3. At such a time, RPG critics will study their gaming history and understand which games accomplished which innovation to the genre, and which simply exploited it commercially. Fallout 3's Brotherhood of Steel" removed any trace of the western Brotherhood from Fallout. It replaced xenophobic military complex with white knight hereos. Well known developers never spoke highly of Bethesda
date: and for good reason. They could never figure out why Bethesda's games should be regarded more highly than their own. They knew that Bethesda was simply lucky to become a RPG phenomenon (thanks to "Open world-mania"
recommended: which had nothing to do with their games). That phenomenon kept alive interest in their (mediocre) gaming endeavours to this day. Nothing else grants the Bethesda more attention than
voteText: the Ubisoft or EA. There was nothing intrinsically better in the Bethesda's games. Brian Fargo of Interplay was certainly a far writer than Todd Howard. Obsidian were certainly much more skilled developers than the 'Greatest Game Developer of Our Generation'. And Rebecca Heineman was a far more accomplished programmer
helpfulPercent: capable of entire games such as "Fallout 1" and "Fallout 2"; not to mention the far greater Slavic programmers who followed them in subsequent decades or the US companies themselves who initially spearheaded what Bethesda merely later repackaged to the masses. Bethesda sold a lot of games not because they are the greatest developers but simply because their games are easy to sell to the masses: it had no difficult content
votesHelpful: it had no technical innovations
votesTotal: it had no creative depth. They wrote a bunch of fun
votesFunny: short stories and they were photogenic. If somebody had not invented "Open world-mania" in 2001
commentsCount: you would not have wasted five minutes of your time reading these pages about such a trivial game developer."
